A 34-year-old woman comes to the outpatient department with complaints of fever for the past 1 month accompanied by weight loss and cough with purulent sputum. The physician suspects tuberculosis and wants to auscultate the apex of the lungs. To hear the breath sounds better, he needs to locate the Triangle of auscultation. All of the following are borders of the Triangle of auscultation, except?

A 50-year-old male known case of chronic kidney disease presents with the complaint of breathlessness for 2 weeks. On examination: heart rate is 100 beats/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and jugular venous pressure is raised with a prominent x-descent. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A sixty-five-year-old presents to your clinic with the complaint of decreased vision in both eyes. The loss of vision was gradual, and he has not experienced any pain in his eyes. Examination findings reveal a bilateral cataract. Cataract surgery is scheduled. The patient is informed that the left eye will be operated on first, and the right eye will be done 1 week after that. An intraocular lens (IOL) is placed in the eye during the surgery. Which type of lens is shown below?

A 40-year old female known case of proximal cholangiocarcinoma underwent percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage as the patient’s bilirubin levels were very high. After the procedure, the patient developed abdominal pain . On further evaluation, the patient was found to have hemobilia due to an iatrogenic trauma to biliary tree. Which of the following statements is the best related to hemobilia?

options.label: A
options.text: Tumors are the most common cause

options.label: B
options.text: The primary treatment of severe hemobilia is surgery

options.label: C
options.text: The classic triad is upper abdominal pain, upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, jaundice

options.label: D
options.text: Ultrasonography usually reveals a specific diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: C. The classic triad is upper abdominal pain, upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, jaundice
questions.explanation:
Hemobilia
  • An abnormal communication between a blood vessel and bile duct causes bleeding into the biliary tree
  • The classic triad is upper abdominal pain, upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and jaundice 
  • The most common cause of hemobilia is iatrogenic trauma, mostly due to percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage from 2% to 10%
  • The test of choice is arterial angiography
  • Most bleeds are managed conservatively; however, angiography with transarterial embolization is indicated for major hemobilia requiring blood transfusion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency with a sudden onset of weakness on the right side of her body and the left side of her face. She has hypertension, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. Examination shows decreased motor tone and power on the right side. On eye examination, she has diplopia on the left lateral gaze. The plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the right side. A CT scan of the head and neck shows a brainstem lesion. What will be the site of the lesion found in this patient?

A 9-year-old boy who is a known case of bronchial asthma comes with a respiratory rate of 48/min, cannot speak 2 words, occasional wheezes, a temperature is 36.8 C and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient has seasonal allergies to ragweed and is also allergic to peanuts. His family history is significant for asthma in his grandfather. You give 3 doses of salbutamol nebulization , and then he started to speak a sentence but oxygen saturation (SaO 2 ) falls to 85%. What is the most likely cause of the drop in oxygen saturation SaO 2 ?

options.text: V / P mismatch with dead space ventilation

A 52-year-old female presents with involuntary, painful muscle contractions in her hands and feet for three days, accompanied by tingling. She has a history of thyroidectomy. Lab tests reveal hypocalcemia . The described muscle activity, when voluntary, mirrors a physiological condition in which muscles achieve maximum tension without subsequent relaxation, similar to post-tetanic potentiation . Which of the following is typically implicated in facilitating this response in muscle tissue?

options.label: C
options.text: A buildup of calcium in the presynaptic terminal

questions.correct_answer: A. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ When the nerves send a weak signal to contract a muscle , the motor units in the muscle that contains the smallest muscle fibers are stimulated in preference to the larger motor units . As the signal increases in strength, larger motor units also begin to be excited .
  • ↳ Gradually, the frequency of muscle contraction also increases, and there comes the point at which a new contraction occurs before the preceding one ends. This second contraction is added partially to the firs t, increasing the total strength of the contraction . When the frequency reaches a n optimum level , the successive contractions f use, and the muscle tension reaches its peak with no relaxation observed, the action appears to be completely smooth ; this is called tetanization. A sustained muscle contraction remains in this stage for some time.
  • ↳ Post-tetanic facilitation is the neuronal phenomenon in which a neuron is more easily excited after a brief period of activity . It occurs after tetanic stimulation of the presynaptic neuron. It is due to the buildup the calcium ions in the presynaptic membrane caused by the prior neur onal activity . Subsequent neuronal impulses release neurotransmitter s more r eadily due to this pre-placed calcium from the pr evious stimulus .
  • ↳ Option A: Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  • ↳ During the depolarisation stage of the action potential , the membrane become s suddenly permeable to sodium ions. Voltage-gated sodium channels open up, allowing many positively charged sodium i ons to flow into the cell's interior . It causes the normal resting negative potential to change into a positive potential. Hence, these channels play a significant role in the depolarisation and repolarization of the nerve membrane.
  • ↳ During the depolarisation stage of the action potential , the membrane become s suddenly permeable to sodium ions. Voltage-gated sodium channels open up, allowing many positively charged sodium i ons to flow into the cell's interior . It causes the normal resting negative potential to change into a positive potential. Hence, these channels play a significant role in the depolarisation and repolarization of the nerve membrane.
  • ↳ Option B: Opening of transmitter-gated potassium channels
  • ↳ Transmitter-gated or ligand-gated potassium ion channels are activated upon binding a neurotransmitter, hormone, or second messengers to the ion channel. They are involved in fast synaptic transmission in the nervous system. The flow of ions across the membrane will either depolarize or hyperpolarization.
  • ↳ Transmitter-gated or ligand-gated potassium ion channels are activated upon binding a neurotransmitter, hormone, or second messengers to the ion channel. They are involved in fast synaptic transmission in the nervous system. The flow of ions across the membrane will either depolarize or hyperpolarization.
  • ↳ Option D: Electrotonic conduction
  • ↳ It is the passive flow of a change in electric potential along a nerve or muscle membrane. It occurs in response to insufficient stimulation to trigger an actively propagated action potential but instead generates depolarisation in a small area of the membrane.
  • ↳ It is the passive flow of a change in electric potential along a nerve or muscle membrane. It occurs in response to insufficient stimulation to trigger an actively propagated action potential but instead generates depolarisation in a small area of the membrane.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an Ophisthotonus posture. When his wife was interviewed, the doctor was informed that he was a chronic alcoholic and had suffered from erectile dysfunction. The couple was told about the medicinal effects of one of the following plant derivatives. The couple had decided to treat him with the powdered form of the seed for the same. The man had become anxious and restless after its consumption. He had also experienced twitching of some muscles before becoming rigid in the Ophisthoptonus posture. Which one could have caused the above-mentioned symptoms?

An 18-year-old boy came to your hospital with complaints of severe abdominal pain. On examination, several new bruises were all over the body. He gives a history of being bullied and punched in the abdomen multiple times forcefully by his classmate . His blood pressure is 140/100 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 102 per minute. The patient is afebrile. Which of the following should be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Component Actions
Primary Assessment

1. Ensure scene safety. 2. Assess the patient's level of consciousness. 3. Check for airway patency. 4. Assess breathing and administer oxygen if needed. 5. Check circulation and control bleeding. 6. Rapid head-to-toe assessment.
Vital Signs 1. Monitor heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation. 2. Establish IV access for fluids and medications. 3. Insert cardiac monitor if needed.
Imaging Studies 1. Perform appropriate X-rays (e.g., chest, pelvis) as needed. 2. Consider FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) ultrasound. 3. CT scans for more detailed evaluation.
Fluid Resuscitation 1. Initiate fluid resuscitation with crystalloids (e.g., normal saline, Ringer's lactate). 2. Use blood products if indicated. 3. Titrate fluids to maintain adequate perfusion.
Pain Management Administer appropriate analgesia and consider pain scales for monitoring. Use caution with narcotics in the setting of possible abdominal injury.
Head Injury 1. Assess Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). 2. Monitor closely for signs of intracranial bleeding or raised intracranial pressure (ICP). 3. Consider CT head if needed.
Cervical Spine Injury Immobilize the cervical spine until cleared based on clinical assessment or imaging. Follow appropriate guidelines for spine clearance.
Abdominal Evaluation Perform focused abdominal examination. Consider CT sca an for abdominal trauma if indicated.
Pelvic Fracture Stabilize unstable pelvic fractures with pelvic binders. Consider angiography for suspected major vascular injury.

A 45-year-old male with dyspepsia, heartburn, and abdominal discomfort, experiencing postprandial nausea, and denies shortness of breath or chest pain. Advised lifestyle changes and a prokinetic drug. Which drug targets serotonin receptors?
questions.explanation:
Treatment Options

Description

Lifestyle Modifications

- Avoiding trigger foods and beverages such as caffeine, chocolate, spicy foods, and citrus fruits
- Elevating the head of the bed
- Maintaining a healthy weight
- Avoiding large meals and eating smaller, more frequent meals
- Quitting smoking
- Limiting alcohol consumption

Medications

- Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs): Examples include omeprazole, esomeprazole, lansoprazole
- H2 Blockers: Examples include ranitidine, famotidine, cimetidine
- Antacids: Examples include aluminum hydroxide, magnesium hydroxide
- Prokinetics (e.g., metoclopramide) in certain cases
- Mosapride (a prokinetic) as an adjunct therapy in some cases

Surgical Intervention

- Fundoplication: A surgical procedure to reinforce the LES and prevent acid reflux
- LINX Device: A magnetic ring implanted around the LES to strengthen it and reduce reflux
- Endoscopic Treatments: Various minimally invasive procedures to tighten the LES and improve symptoms

options.text: No change in pattern of breathing

questions.text: A 23-year-old female is scheduled to undergo a rotator cuff repair. Her medical history is significant for severe asthma and gastroesophageal reflux disease, both of which are only moderately well controlled. She has no medication allergies but is allergic to eggs and soy. If performing general anaesthesia with an endotracheal tube on this patient, which of the following induction agents would be ideal?

A 7-month-old male has been brought to the emergency department unconscious. On examination, the baby does not have a pulse. His blood pressure is not recordable. Which of the following is the least likely included in the ACLS guideline?

options.label: A
options.text: Compressions: ventilation ratio is 15:2 when more than one rescuer is present in an infant

options.label: C
options.text: The ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 for a single rescuer

options.label: D
options.text: The depth of compression should be more than or equal to one-third of the anteroposterior diameter of the chest

questions.correct_answer: B. Brachial pulse check every 2 minutes

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida, 38 weeks pregnant, presented to the labour room in active labour. She is a case of a ventricular septal defect which was corrected. What are the most appropriate anaesthetic considerations for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Elective cesarean section with spinal anesthesia and invasive monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following is the component of the Weaning criteria of ventilation?

A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with the complaint of abdominal pain for the past 2 years. She states that she frequently has cramps and lower abdominal pain that lasts for a few days and is usually at the same time every month. She has not attained menarche yet, and she attained breast and pubic hair development at 12. On examination, she has a moderately tender suprapubic mass. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
Which hormone is responsible for the mid-cycle rise in body temperature in females?

A 30-year-old P2L2 woman with previous 2 vaginal deliveries presents for a routine pap smear. She complains of occasional mucoid vaginal discharge and no other significant complaints. On per speculum examination, the cervical os is expected to appear:

A 48-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with the complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding. Her pelvic examination is unremarkable, and her recent pelvic scan shows no pelvic pathology. An office endometrial aspiration shows simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Simple hyperplasia with out Atypia is 1%
Complex hyperplasia with out Atypia 3%
Simple hyperplasia with Atypia 8%
Complex hyperplasia with Atypia 29%

questions.text: A pregnant woman, currently at 34 weeks of gestation, arrives at the obstetric clinic reporting a sudden gush of fluid from the vagina, resulting in soaking of her clothes. The woman has no abdominal pain, and she does not perceive any contractions. What would be the most appropriate initial clinical examination to determine the cause of this presentation?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the fertility clinic for preconception counselling. She has epilepsy and wants to know about its risk in pregnancy and for her baby. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding epilepsy in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The rate of congenital malformation is not significantly increased in the offspring of women with epilepsy not on anticonvulsant therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Seizure frequency increases in approximately 70% of women

options.label: C
options.text: Breastfeeding is safe with most anticonvulsants

options.label: D
options.text: Folic acid supplementation may reduce the risk of neural tube defects

questions.correct_answer: B. Seizure frequency increases in approximately 70% of women

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and vomiting. Upon examination, she is found to have alopecia with exclamation mark hair. She also has crepitus in the epigastrium. What is the diagnosis?

A 35-year-old non-pregnant female presents to a surgical outpatient department with complaints of fever, anorexia, pelvic pain, diarrhea, and passage of mucus in the stools . Physical examination is generally unremarkable except for mild pelvic tenderness and bulging of the anterior rectal wall on digital rectal examination. An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a pus-filled collection in the rectouterine pouch. What is the best next step in the management of this case?

A 2-week-old male child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal distension, incessant crying, and failure to take feeds. What does the marked white arrow in the x-ray show?

A 19-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to burns to the chest, arms and legs . Her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, her pulse is 80/min, and her respiratory rate 18/minute. On physical examination, the patient appears in pain with full awareness. She has deep second degree burns to the chest, arms, and forearms. When can we expect the patient to have re-epithelialization of the burn wound?
questions.explanation:
Superficial second-degree burns Deep second-degree burns
  • In superficial second-degree burns, the burn depth goes no deeper than the papillary dermis
  • Superficial second-degree burns spontaneously epithelialize from retained epidermal structures in the rete ridges, hair follicles and sweat glands in 1 to 2 weeks
  • Deep second-degree burns into the reticular dermis appear pale and mottled, do not blanch to touch but remain painful to pinprick
  • These burns heal in 2 to 5 weeks by re-epithelialization from hair follicles and sweat gland keratinocytes, often with severe scarring as a result of the loss of dermis

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient complains of prolonged bleeding from an ulcer over the right lower limb. The daily dressings with non-adherent paraffin gas patients have been performed since then, but the ulcer did not heal. Hence, he undergoes debridement and Thiersch grafting of the right leg ulcer under spinal anesthesia. Which of the following is the advantage of the type of graft used in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: The graft can not be taken from the upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall

options.label: D
options.text: The is not affected by the hematoma

questions.correct_answer: A. Large-size grafts can be taken
questions.explanation:
Type of Graft

Advantages

Disadvantages

Thin Split

Thickness

  • Best Survival
  • Heals Rapidly
  • Least resembles original skin.
  • Least resistance to trauma.
  • Poor Sensation
  • Maximal Secondary Contraction 

Thick Split

Thickness

 
  • More qualifies of normal skin.
  • Less Contraction
  • Looks better
  • Fair Sensation

 
  • Lower graft survival
  • Slower healing.

 

Full Thickness

 
  • Most resembles normal skin.
  • Minimal Secondary contraction
  • Resistant to trauma
  • Good Sensation
  • Aesthetically pleasing
  • Poorest survival.
  • Donor site must be closed surgically.
  • Donor sites are limited.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency department with acute abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He is immediately taken up for emergency laparotomy. Resection of the bowel with ileostomy is done. Examination of the specimen reveals a segmental disease with aphthous ulcers and non-caseating granulomas with Langerhans giant cells . What diagnostic modality is most commonly used to diagnose the above clinical condition?

A 32-year-old woman presented to the physician's clinic with a complaint of thin whitish vaginal discharge for the past week. On physical examination, the discharge is seen and vaginal discharge sample is collected, and the examination findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the disease caused by the organism seen around the vaginal cells in the image?

A 25-year-old female, gravida 2 para 1, presents to the labour room due to heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours at 30 weeks of gestation. The patient reports no uterine contractions or pain. Her blood pressure is 80/60mmHg.Transabdominal ultrasound reveals a central placenta previa. Multiple transfusions of cross-matched blood are given to resuscitate the patient before she undergoes a caesarean section to deliver the fetus. Which of the following is the most likely future complication for this patient?

A 39-year-old woman comes to the fertility clinic for infertility evaluation. She has been unable to conceive for 3 years. She and her partner are sexually active and do not use contraception. Analysis of her husband's semen showed normal sperm counts. The treating doctor checks her FSH on day 3 and repeats it on day 10 after 5 days of Clomiphene citrate (100mg). The values noted were 20 IU/L and 35 IU/L, respectively. The most probable cause of infertility in this patient is?

A 16-year-old girl presented to the clinic with a history of nasal obstruction for the last 2 months. It was associated with a headache and a loss of sense of smell. There is no history of epistaxis. The physician ordered an X-ray, and the following findings were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A previously healthy, active 18-month-old child presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge for 3 months. The mother does not complaint of any fever. The child does not have any significant medical history. The child's examination is otherwise unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Benign and Malignant Tumors of the Nasopharynx  
Benign Malignant
Angiofibroma Carcinoma nasopharynx
Choanal polyp Lymphoma
Squamous papilloma Rhabdomyosarcoma
Thornwaldt's cyst Chordoma
Pleomorphic adenoma Plasmacytoma
Craniopharyngioma Haemangiopericytoma
Paraganglioma Malignant salivary gland tumors
Hamartoma  
  • Congenital tumors
    • Hairy polyp
    • Teratoma
    • Epignathioma
 Melanoma

Causes of unilateral nasal obstruction Causes of Bilateral Nasal obstruction
1.Structural: DNS, inf.turbinate hypertrophy, concha bullosa

1.Infection:

  • Acute rhinitis
  • CRS, Atrophic rhinitis
2.Infection: Unilateral sinusitis 2.Allergy: Allergic rhinitis
3.Polyp: Antrochoanal polyp

3.Non allergic, non infective:

Vasomotor rhinitis
4.FB 4.Adenoid hypertrophy
5.Neoplasms 5.Structural: DNS
6.Congenital:choanal atresia 6.Trauma: Septal hematoma
7.Trauma 7. Ethmoidal polyposis
8.Granulomatous Dx: Rhinoscleroma 8.Neoplasms
  9.Rhinitis medicamentosa

questions.text: A 1-day-old male baby was admitted to NICU after being delivered vaginally to a multiparous diabetic woman at home by a midwife. He had a weak cry, flaccid muscle tone, and a pulse of 98 bpm. He was immediately resuscitated for his poor APGAR score . The doctor examined him thoroughly for his physical and neuromuscular maturity . Which of the following tests is done to assess the passive tone of shoulder flexors in the Ballard score?

A 16-month-old baby boy is brought to the pediatric OPD with a complaint of eating mud, chalk, and other non-nutritive things for the last two months . The mother says no matter how much they try giving him good food at regular intervals throughout the day, he does not stop eating mud. What abnormality does this child have ?

A 5-year-old child presented with a sore throat and swelling of the neck. On examination of the throat, the following was seen: The child is never immunized. What is the most probable causative organism?

A pregnant lady had complaints of mild cervical lymphadenopathy in the first trimester. She was prescribed Spiramycin , but she was non-compliant. The baby was born with hydrocephalus and intracerebral calcification . Which of these is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Congenital Infections

                              Physical findings

 Toxoplasma

 

 

  • Hydrocephalus

  • Chorioretinitis

  • Diffuse cerebral calcifications.

 

Cytomegalovirus

 

  • Intrauterine growth retardation

  • Microcephaly

  • Periventricular calcifications

  • Hepatosplenomegaly

  • Prolonged neonatal jaundice

  • Generalized blue–purple macular rash

Varicella Zoster virus

 

  • Cicatrizing skin lesions

  • Hypoplasia of all limbs

  • Chorioretinitis

Rubella

 

  • Cataract

  • Deafness (Sensorineural hearing loss)

  • Congenital heart disease (Patent ductus arteriosus)

questions.text: A certain syndicate has acquired the rights to excavate a part of a forest area for the construction of a factory. During the excavation, the remains of a couple of bodies have been recovered. It has been sent to the forensic lab for the determination of its identity. The forensic team would use all of the following formulae to determine the sex of the bone . Which among them is not the right method ?

options.label: A
options.text: Sciatic notch index - Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100

options.label: B
options.text: Washburn ischiopubic index - Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100

options.label: C
options.text: Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100

options.label: D
options.text: Sternal index - Manubrial length/ Body length x 100

questions.correct_answer: C. Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100
questions.explanation:
Name of the index Formulae Males Females
Sciatic notch index Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100 4-5 5-6
Washburn ischiopubic index Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100 73-94 91-115
Corporobasal index of sacrum Breadth of 1st sacral vertebra/ Breadth of base of sacrum x 100 45 40.5
Sternal index Manubrial length/ Body length x 100 46.2 54.3

questions.text: A 30-year-old man and his parents have been arrested under IPC 314 after the death of the man's 26-year-old wife. What offence are they being charged for?

options.label: B
options.text: Death of the patient caused by intent to cause miscarriage

options.label: D
options.text: Death of the child during intent to cause miscarriage

questions.correct_answer: B. Death of the patient caused by intent to cause miscarriage
questions.explanation:
Offence

Punishment

S.312
  • Causing miscarriage
  • If the woman be quick with child
  • 3 years or fine or both
  • 7 years + fine

S.313
  • Causing miscarriage without a woman’s consent
  • Life or ten years + fine.

S.314
  • Death caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage
  • If an act is done without a woman’s consent
  • 10 years + fine.
  • Life or ten years + fine.

S.315
  • An act was done with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause it to die after birth
  • Ten years + fine

S.316
  • Causing the death of a quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide
  • Ten years + fine

questions.text: The body of the 27-year-old female tourist, who had been missing for a week, has been recovered from near a waterfall. The forensic team has begun its investigation to determine the cause of death. Among the findings, the team has documented the presence of Masque Ecchymotique, which indicates the possible cause of death as?

A 40-year-old man presented to the emergency with a complaint of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on mild-moderate exertion for 2 days . On physical examination, the neck veins are distended, elevated JVP and breath sounds are normal bilaterally . An urgent chest x-ray is done, as shown below. Based on the image given below, what is the correct diagnosis ?
A statistical study was conducted by a group of community medicine students. Power of study can be increased by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
TYPE 1 ERROR TYPE 2 ERROR
Null hypothesis is true but rejected Null hypothesis is false but accepted
p-value Beta error
Probability of concluding the treatments differ when in reality they dont Probability of concluding the treatments don't differ when in reality they do
False positive False negative
Not affected by sample size Depends on sample size
More serious Less serious
For statistical significance For power of a test

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl previously diagnosed with Noonan Syndrome presented to the pediatric clinic with complaints of vomiting and diarrhoea for the past 4 days. She is given treatment for acute gastroenteritis. On physical examination, she has short stature, a webbed neck, cubitus valgus and anti-mongoloid eyes. She is unable to understand and follow the command. A systolic ejection murmur is heard in the pulmonary area on auscultation of the heart. Now the paediatrician has suspicion of Turner syndrome. Which of the following is the main differentiating feature between the two syndromes?
questions.explanation:
Similarities with Turner Syndrome

Differences with Turner Syndrome

  • Webbed neck
  • Short stature
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Delayed puberty but fertility is normal whereas infertility seen in Turner syndrome
  • Intellectual disability not seen in Turner but seen in Noonan syndrome
  • Noonan is seen in both boys and girls → Karyotype is normal. Turner is seen only in girls.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents in the emergency department with complaint of pain and fullness in the ear. The patient has also noticed that his hearing has reduced over the last 2 years and presented with the following otoscopic finding. Similar findings can also be seen in which of the following conditions?

A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of pruritic lesions on the foot. He is a farmer. He states that the lesions are itchy. On examination, the serpiginous pattern of the skin lesion, as shown in the image below, is noted: In which of the following diseases can these lesions be seen?

A 8-year-old boy comes to the ER after 7 days of vomiting and diarrhea, advised 'Plan B' for dehydration. Returns 5 days later with muscle weakness and cramps due to poor compliance. Physical exam normal, CT scan clear. ECG shows changes. Which electrolyte abnormalities cause these ECG changes ? Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities produce these changes in an ECG?

A 32-year-old male presents with weakness on the left side of the face, inability to close his left eye, drooping of the mouth, and drooling of saliva. There is no wrinkling on the left side of the forehead. The rest of the examination findings are shown below. The structure damaged in the given condition is responsible for all of the following except?

options.label: A
options.text: Taste sensation of anterior2/3 rd tongue

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic for his routine annual visit. The patient has complained of an abnormal gait for 2 weeks. On physical examination, the patient's pelvis dips on the right side with his right foot in the air and left foot on the ground. A photo of the patient's gait is shown below. Weakness of which of the following muscles is responsible for this patient’s presentation? Weakness of which of the following muscles is responsible for this patient’s presentation?

A 6-month-old child with diarrhea for 2 days presents in a drowsy state . His mother complains that he has not taken any feed since morning and is less responsive to her. On examination, there is tachycardia and tachypnea . He has a very slow skin tone, sunken eyes, and a depressed fontanel. How is the skin pinch said to be very slow?
questions.explanation:
No Dehydration Some Dehydration Severe Dehydration
Consciousness Alert "Irritable" "Lethargic"
Eyes Normal Sunken Very sunken
Thirst Normal "Drinks eagerly" "Unable to drink."
Buccal mucosa Normal Dry Very dry
Skin pinch Goes back quickly "Slowly" "Very slowly"
Tears Present Absent Absent

questions.text: Which spinal segments originate from the nerve marked in the neck region shown below?

A 78-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening fatigue and headache for 6 months and occasional upper abdominal pain. He does not drink alcohol and does not smoke. His diet has mostly consisted of potatoes and eggs since his wife passed away 1 year ago. His pulse is 92/min, and his blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival and mucosal pallor. Abdominal and rectal examination shows no abnormalities The peripheral blood smear of the patient is illustrated in the image below: Which of the following is the likely aetiology responsible for the clinical manifestation of this patient?

A 53-year-old male presents to his family physician for physical insurance . During the history taking, the doctor came to know that his father had diabetes and died because of congestive heart failure. The patient was told that his father had "bronze diabetes." The patient complains only of arthralgias and vague fatigue . The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The investigation of the patient revealed high levels of serum iron and ferritin . The doctor is concerned that the patient might be at risk of hereditary hemochromatosis . Which of the following tests would the doctor order to confirm his suspicion?

A 68-year-old woman undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer presents with a four -day history of fever and chest pain . The cardiac catheter examination shows a significantly reduced ejection fraction with normal coronary blood flow; a myocardial biopsy is taken, and a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test for C oxsackie virus is positive for this patient's myocardium is likely to show an increase in which of the following inflammatory cells?

A 24-year-old woman presents to the hospital for a follow-up examination. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) and received an allogeneic bone marrow transplant 3 weeks ago. She complains of a skin rash and diarrhoea for three days. Liver function tests show an increase in AST and ALT levels. A skin biopsy reveals a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis and epidermis and apoptotic cells in the basal cell layer of the epidermis. Which of the following cells is the primary cause of this patient's skin rash and diarrhoea?

A 62-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type II for 15 years and end-stage renal disease for 1 year undergoes a kidney transplant in a tertiary care hospital. After three weeks, she complains of fever and pain in the graft region. Further assessment reveals diminished urine output. Laboratory evaluation shows markedly raised creatinine and blood urea nitrogen. On a kidney biopsy, which of the following pathologic findings should be expected?

options.label: A
options.text: Arterial intimal thickening and vascular stenosis

options.label: C
options.text: Interstitial infiltrates of lymphocytes and macrophages

questions.correct_answer: C. Interstitial infiltrates of lymphocytes and macrophages

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of recent easy fatigability, bruising, and recurrent throat infections. Physical examination reveals numerous petechiae over her body and mouth. Abnormal laboratory findings include haemoglobin of 6 g/dL, WBC of 1,500/mL, and platelets of 20,000/mL. The bone marrow is hypocellular and displays increased fat. What is the appropriate diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of tingling in her hands and feet for 1 day with rapidly progressing severe muscle cramps, laryngeal stridor, and convulsions. Moreover, she has undergone a total thyroidectomy 2 days earlier for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Which laboratory findings would be expected in this patient before initiating treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased serum calcium and decreased PTH

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased serum calcium and increased PTH

options.label: C
options.text: Increased serum calcium and decreased PTH

options.label: D
options.text: Increased serum calcium and increased PTH

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased serum calcium and increased PTH

questions.text: A 34-years-old male presents to the physician with complaints of small painless nodules on his penis for 5 days. He further explains that later, the nodules burst and created open, fleshy, oozing lesions, becoming a beefy red ulcer in the genital region. He is a sexual history and is HIV positive. He is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Which of the following organism is involved in the patient's current pathology?

The skeletal muscle morphology comprises many structural proteins, and their interaction brings about skeletal muscle contraction. Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic muscle picture?

A practical lab is arranged for students to make them learn about muscle contraction. Frogs after dissection are used as specimens. Electrodes are connected to the exposed muscle of the frog leg to induce muscle twitch. Students find out that the latent period of muscle cramps is 10 ms, the contraction period is 40 ms, and the relaxation time is 50 ms. What would be the tetanizing frequency?

A 38-year-old male visits the clinic complaining of progressively enlarging discolored whitish patches near both ankles for the last five months. He has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. On examination, hypopigmented patches are present near both ankles with surrounding normal skin. The rest of the body is spared. Which of the following has no documented role in managing this patient's underlying condition?

A 70-year-old male patient had Parkinson's disease diagnosed. He was examined by a neurologist and was started on a combination of carbidopa and levodopa medication. Although the prescribing physician noted no improvement in his parkinsonian symptoms, the medication was continued. The patient developed memory problems a year later, and Alzheimer's disease was diagnosed. Recently, the patient began experiencing frequent visual hallucinations. The provisional diagnosis of Lewy body dementia was made, and the patient was given donepezil 5 mg at bedtime, and levodopa was stopped. He showed improvement. All of the following can be seen in this patient, except
questions.explanation:
Revised criteria for the clinical diagnosis of

Lewy body dementia:

1. Fluctuating cognition

2. Recurrent Visual hallucination

3. REM sleep behavior disorder

4. Cardinal features of Parkinsonism (one or more)

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented to the hospital with profuse watery diarrhoea, vomiting, stomach pain, leg cramps and irritability. The physician is suspecting cholera as the diagnosis. Which of the following is an inappropriate statement regarding the given condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Azithromycin is first like drug for adults

options.label: D
options.text: It is a notifiable disease locally, nationally, and internationally

questions.correct_answer: C. Azithromycin is first like drug for adults
questions.explanation:
Groups Antibiotic of choice for cholera
Adults Doxycycline (hence option-C is wrong)
Children Azithromycin
Pregnancy Azithromycin
Chemoprophylaxis Tetracycline

questions.text: A study comparing cases with non-cases of breast cancer found that 75/100 cases used calcium supplements compared with 25/100 of the non-cases. What is the cross-product ratio of this study?
questions.explanation:
Breast Cancer Cases Non-cases
Used Ca supplements 75 (a) 25 (b)
Did not use Ca supplements 25 (c) 75 (d)
  100 100

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic to evaluate the back pain and pain in her hands . She has a regular menstrual cycle and does not take any medication. She also complained of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, no swelling, neurologic features, or visible deformities are noted. She denies any fever or morning stiffness. Serum calcium is elevated in the laboratory analysis . An X-ray of the hands shows the following findings. Which of the following finding is not seen in this condition?

A patient previously diagnosed with chronic congestive heart failure came in for a regular check-up. ECG taken revealed a short QTc , and given that the patient has had a history of kidney stones, you suspect it could be due to hypercalcemia. The serum electrolytes test indicates a calcium level of 12.5 mg/dL . Which diuretic among the following would you choose to manage this patient, considering the added requirement to alleviate hypercalcemia?
questions.explanation:
Loop diuretics Thiazide diuretics
  • Act on Na+K+2Cl- symporter
  • Acts on ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
  • Includes- furosemide, torsemide, bumetanide
  • High ceiling diuretics
  • Loop loses calcium – therefore used in hypercalcemia
  • Inhibits Na-Cl- symporter
  • Acts on the distal tubule
  • Includes- chlorthiazide, indapamide
  • Decreases Na+, K+, Mg2+, H+
  • Increases glucose, uric acid, lipid
  • Increase in calcium - used in osteoporosis

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presents to the outpatient department for a follow-up checkup. The patient is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, he appears healthy; his pulse is 76/min, respirations are 15/min, and his blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. While reviewing medications, it is noted that the patient is taking oral theophylline and inhaled fluticasone. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of theophylline?

For a 43-year-old woman with endometriosis and a family history of uterine fibroids and ischemic heart disease, which treatment option would not be considered due to its short-term use of 6 months to prepare for surgery?
Which of the following is a gender-specific adverse effect of valproate?

A young male patient, aged 20 years , presents to OPD with recurrent oral pain and genital ulcers; he further states that the oral ulcers have healed without a scar but the genital ulcers healed with scars. He also complains of skin bumps over his trunk that appear as subcutaneous nodules. He also complained of headaches and blurred vision for 1 week. As he visited the doctor and underwent investigations, his HLA B51 was positive. Which criteria are in the revised guidelines to diagnose this condition?

A 23-year-old man with hallucinations, abdominal pain, and weakness in upper extremities. He smokes a pack a day for two months. The deep tendon reflexes are decreased in the upper extremities.. Normal vital signs and lab parameters except for urine color change. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's underlying condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an autosomal recessive disease

options.label: B
options.text: This condition is exacerbated by progesterone

options.label: C
options.text: Photosensitivity can be seen in severe sun exposure

questions.correct_answer: B. This condition is exacerbated by progesterone

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented to the physician’s office complaining of palpitations and dizziness for the past few weeks. She had no history of syncope and was taking medication for rate control. On physical examination, the pulse is 69 beats per minute, and the blood pressure is 85/69 mm Hg. Which of the following is the best drug for the rhythm disorder shown below?

ASSERTION: A decreased calcium level interferes with blood clotting in a healthy person. REASON: Calcium is coagulation factor IV. Which of the following conclusions about the assertion and the reason is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for 2 days. The pain began after she tried to move some heavy objects off the floor. The patient identifies the pain as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The patient also reports that she has had intermittent diarrhoea, bloating, and a 12-kg weight loss for the past 3 years. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years, and her menstrual cycle is irregular. She is inconsistent with her diet. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears pale. Investigation of choice in COPD?
questions.explanation:
Type of COPD Description
Chronic Bronchitis - Characterized by chronic inflammation of the bronchial tubes (airways).
  - Excessive mucus production, leading to cough with sputum production.
  - Often associated with recurrent respiratory infections.
Emphysema - Involves damage to the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs.
  - Loss of lung elasticity and reduced ability to exhale air effectively.
  - Leads to air trapping and increased work of breathing.
Mixed COPD - Some individuals may have features of both chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
  - Commonly referred to as "mixed" or "overlap" COPD.
Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency-Related COPD - Caused by a genetic deficiency of alpha-1 antitrypsin, an enzyme that protects the lungs from damage.
  - Can result in early-onset COPD, especially in non-smokers.

A 43-year-old male with a history of multiple episodes of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain showed a ringed esophagus on a barium meal X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following characteristics make teduglutide a favourable drug in a patient diagnosed with short bowel syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to speed up defecation

questions.text: An infant was born by cesarean delivery at 33 weeks of gestational age. At birth, the infant had generalized hemorrhagic purpura (a blueberry muffin rash) over the entire body, patent ductus arteriosus, cardiomegaly, thrombocytopenia, pneumonitis, anemia, and liver dysfunction. Which of the following is most likely to cause this condition?

A 28-year-old male sewerage worker presents to the physician with complaints of fever along with jaundice and conjunctivitis for 1 week. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. His blood sample was taken and sent to the lab. Lab findings are suggestive of kidney failure and elevated hepatic enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

You have a clinic set up in your hometown. A 42 year old male walks in and complains of generalized fatigue. On examination, almost everything seems to be normal except for his blood pressure, which was about 142/92 mmHg. Further probing revealed no comorbidities and an insignificant family history. Which of the following medications would you prefer as the first choice of treatment for this patient?

An accredited social health activist is a community health worker instituted by the government of India's Ministry of Health and Family Welfare as a part of the National Rural Health Mission. Which of the following is true about incentives given to ASHA workers in Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?

options.label: A
options.text: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in rural area in high performing states

options.label: B
options.text: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in rural area in low performing states

options.label: C
options.text: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban area high performing states

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban area low performing states

Respired lung weight as compared to body weight is?

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman known case of Hypertension presented with complaints of sudden onset headache, which she described as a characteristic thunderclap headache. There are no associated symptoms like watery eyes, photophobia, or phonophobia. Her GCS is 15/15, and she is vitally stable. On examination, her pupils are dilated bilaterally . These findings are most likely consistent with which of the following diagnosis?

A 49-year-old male patient presents with complaints of achy swollen joints, fatigue, skin rash, especially on the face, and difficulty in deep breathing. The senior resident doctor explains that it is related to immune competency and asks to study the complement pathway. Which of the following is involved in complement activation via an alternative pathway?

A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings: Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 5-year-old male child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic by his mother with complaints of blurring of vision for one week. For a detailed examination of the eye, the doctor uses a short-acting medication which also has a cycloplegic effect . Which of the following drugs was used by the doctor in this case?

A 26-year-old female labourer by occupation presents to the outpatient department with complaints of pain abdomen, nausea and restlessness for 4 hours. She gives the history of 2 episodes of hematuria. USG shows a 2×3 cm stone in the Right renal pelvis. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis . Which of the following is the best procedure for managing this patient?

A 35-year individual with a known case of HIV presents to the outpatient with complaints of blurry vision , sighting spots and floaters, and flashing lights. He also had a new found sensitivity to light and pain in the eyes. He underwent a Fundal examination which showed a Pizza appearance . Which of the following will be the commonest etiological agent in this case?

A 38-year-old woman with P2L2 complains of heavy menstrual cycles with the passage of blood clots for 7 to 10 days each month for the past 1 year. She has only transient relief with medicines (the nature of medicines is unknown). On examination, the uterus is 18 cm in size. A USG shows an intramural fibroid size of 16 x 18 cm and an endometrial thickness of 4mm. Her Hb is 6.7 g/dL. What is the treatment of choice?

options.label: A
options.text: Hb build-up and medical management with GnRH agonists/ mifepristone and follow-up.

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnostic and therapeutic D&C, if biopsy normal, myomectomy after blood transfusion

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with PCOS undergoing fertility treatment with clomiphene citrate and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) injections complained of severe abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. On examination, she had moderate ascites, tachycardia, and hypotension. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.

options.label: B
options.text: The symptoms are likely related to ectopic pregnancy.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient is at high risk for ovarian torsion.

options.label: D
options.text: The findings are consistent with a normal response to fertility treatments.

questions.correct_answer: A. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.

questions.text: Many young adults & children are admitted to emergency department with complaint of exacerbation of asthma on May 2nd which is a very hot day. There is no history of chronic bronchitis/ heart disease among these patients. Which of the following pollutant is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Ozone at ground level (not to be confused with the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere) is one of the major constituents of photochemical smog. Highest levels of ozone pollution occurs during periods of sunny weather. Excessive ozone in the air can have a marked effect on human health. It can cause breathing problems, trigger asthma, reduce lung function and cause lung diseases.
  • ➤ Ozone at ground level (not to be confused with the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere) is one of the major constituents of photochemical smog.
  • ➤ Highest levels of ozone pollution occurs during periods of sunny weather.
  • ➤ Excessive ozone in the air can have a marked effect on human health.
  • ➤ It can cause breathing problems, trigger asthma, reduce lung function and cause lung diseases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who works in a textile company visited the hospital for a routine health check-up. He prepares dyes for the company for the last 18 years. Which of the following investigation would you recommend for this patient?

A 6-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, joint stiffness, aggressive behavior, and poor language skills; however, his vision is clear. Increased urinary excretion of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis among the following diseases?
Which of the following structures is located within the superficial perineal pouch?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with numbness and tingling sensations on the lateral aspect of his left arm after a road traffic accident. Considering the damage to the axillary nerve, which type of axons appear to be spared with this presentation?

An 8-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, fever, loss of appetite, and severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain for 6 hours. Diagnosis indicates acute appendicitis . During an appendectomy at McBurney's point, what structure is most likely to be injured?

50 year old male, known case of diverticulosis of the colon presents with complaints of left lower quadrant pain and bloody stools. He was taken up for follow up testing. Doctor begins his workup with appropriate test of the sigmoid colon and operates, by recalling which of it’s specific feature:

options.label: B
options.text: Has teniae coli and epiploic appendages

options.label: C
options.text: Receives parasympathetic fibers from the vagus nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Receives its blood from the superior mesenteric artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Has teniae coli and epiploic appendages

questions.text: A 56-year-old male was undergoing surgery for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck. The surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery during the surgery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?

A man named Papa had been suspended from college because of missing many classes. His sister said that she had often seen him mumbling quietly to himself and at times he seemed to be talking to people who were not there. He would emerge from his room and ask his family to be quiet even when they were not making any noise. He was found to be a poorly groomed young man who seemed inattentive and preoccupied. His family said that they had never known him to use drugs or alcohol. He had been like this for the last 8 months and his condition is deteriorating gradually. Which of the following personality disorders is most prevalent among relatives of this patient?

A 14-year-old boy presented to the medical outpatient department with a complaint o fever, sore throat, and malaise. On throat examination, reddened enlarged tonsils are seen, an d the pharynx is inflamed. There is splenomegaly o n abdominal examination. The patient also complains of extreme fatigue. What is the best test for confirmation of a causative agent?

A 30-year-old infertile patient presents with chronic lower abdominal pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. She has regular cycles and today is the 25th day of her period. On vaginal examination, there is pelvic tenderness and nodularity in the posterior fornix. The most probable diagnosis is?

A 45-year-old male presented to the emergency with a complaint of chest pain associated with swallowing a piece of meat. He reports similar episodes over the past 3 years. However, today's episode was the most severe. He does not give a history of regurgitation other than these episodes or heartburn symptoms. There is no difficulty in liquid intake, and he has not had any weight loss. A probable diagnosis in this case is?

A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a fever at 19 weeks of pregnancy. She tests positive for COVID-19 on PCR. She desires to know the effects of the disease on her baby. The risk of which of the following complications is increased in a case of pregnancy with COVID-19?

In a physiology class, you are being taught about feedback mechanisms. The professor describes the importance of feedback mechanisms and various types of feedback mechanisms. Which among the following are examples of positive feedback mechanisms? 1. Oxytocin in parturition 2. Action potential of neuron from RMP to the action potential 3. LH surge leading to ovulation 4. Platelet plug/clot formation

A 53-year-old female presents to the clinic for a regular health checkup. A routine abdominal radiograph is performed, which shows a porcelain gall bladder. Cholecystectomy is advised. Which of the following is the nerve supply to the gall bladder?

A primigravida presented in labor at term pregnancy. An emergency LSCS had to be performed due to fetal distress. During the cesarean section, placenta delivery was followed by heavy bleeding from the placental bed. In order, the obstetrician injected oxytocin, injection methergine, rectal misoprostol, and intramyometrial prostodin. However, the bleeding did not stop. A few compression sutures over the uterus were taken, which also did not stop the bleeding completely, and the uterus remained atonic. Which is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Two-layer closure of the uterine incision

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 26 weeks of gestation for a routine antenatal visit. On examination, her BP is 154/ 92 mmHg, and her PR is 88/min. Systemic and abdominal examinations are normal. Her previous BP records have been normal. Her weight gain in the last 2 weeks is 2 kgs. Her blood tests show Hb 12 gm%, TLC 8400/cu.mm, platelet count 200,000/mL, RBS is 116 mg/dL, serum Bilirubin: 0.6 mg/dL, and serum creatinine 0.8 mg/dL. Her 24-hour urine protein is 345 mg/day. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gestational hypertension BP 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks, and proteinuria is not present.
Preeclampsia BP 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks of gestation, and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).
Eclampsia Pre-eclampsia + seizures
Chronic hypertension BP >140/90 mm Hg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.
Pre-eclampsia superimposed on chronic hypertension
  1. New onset proteinuria first time after 20 weeks in chronic hypertensive
  2. Sudden increase in BP or proteinuria or thrombocytopenia (<100,000/cu.mm) in chronic hypertensive with proteinuria

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 26 weeks with a painless ulcer on her labia. On examination, the ulcer appears raised with a firm border, reddish in color, non-tender, and smooth ulcer base without any significant pus. There are also associated lymph nodes that are not indurated or tender. Minimal exudate expressed from the ulcer on dark field microscopy shows motile spirochetes. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A 30-year-old male comes to the physician for a routine health examination. The patient is an office worker, so he does less exercise. The patient is worried that the lack of exercise might decrease his health. He has no history of any chronic illness. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Which of the following is a healthy cardiac reserve in this patient?

questions.text: Raju, a 45 year old male, has recently undergone corneal transplantation. After the corneal transplant, the risk of the development of corneal infection increases. Which of the following infections is more common following corneal transplantation?
